awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH:  INTEGRATING FOSSIL AND MODERN EVIDENCE TO DETERMINE THE ROLE OF DIET IN MAMMALIAN DIVERSIFICATION
awd_abstract_narration:
Mammals have evolved diverse diets to fuel their demanding metabolisms. This study will investigate the role diet played in mammalian diversification by combining data from the fossil record with data on living mammals. Work will focus on three groups with good fossil records and variable diets:  Primates, Carnivora (e.g. dogs, cats and bears), and Cetartiodactyla (e.g. deer, cows and whales). A combination of morphological and DNA data will be used to produce a time-calibrated phylogeny of each group that includes fossil and living species. These phylogenetic trees will then be analyzed with dietary data to estimate speciation and extinction rates in mammals with different diets. The results will be compared to traditional paleontological methods to quantify the biases of these different approaches in reconstructing diversification history.

This study of mammalian dietary evolution will elucidate the evolutionary role diet played in the origin of living mammals, including humans, and whether the evolutionary trajectory of omnivory in our ancestors paralleled its origin in other primates. It will also contribute to consilience between paleontological and phylogenetic approaches to macroevolutionary biology, facilitating interdisciplinary collaboration. The project will support training of undergraduate and graduate students along with the development of K-16 educational materials.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to integrate paleontological and neontological data in examining the evolution of diet among mammals, with a particular focus on mammals from three mammalian orders: Artiodactyla (cloven-hoofed ungulates), Primates (monkeys and apes), and Carnivora (dogs, cats, and other predatory mammals). These groups served as a study system for our efforts to ascertain how data could be integrated between fossil and modern study systems. We focused on diet as a fundamental ecological parameter that is relatively easy to reconstruct from mammalian fossil remains. Because of the influence of diet on so many other ecological parameters, it offers an excellent subject for macroevolutionary studies. We focused on the relationship between diet and rates of diversification, as well as evolutionary trajectories between different ecological roles.

One of the critical tasks that our project required was generating evolutionary trees including fossil and modern taxa. While there are, in theory, frameworks for integrating the molecular genetic data available for extant species with the morphological data used to reconstruct relationships among extinct species, we discovered in the course of assembling the information we needed to pursue our analyses that the data available are often inadequate for the demands of large scale analyses. While it would be ideal to assemble all the character data for fossil and living species and analyze them simultaneously, we have little or no molecular data for extinct species, nor are ever likely to; original organic material is very rarely preserved in fossils more than about 100,000 years old and is hard to sequence even in those relatively young specimens. There is also surprisingly little morphological character data available for living species, as paleontological studies often will collect data on only a few living species. Given these data differences, we have generated our large-scale phylogenies of Carnivorans using supertree methods that essentially graft fossils into the evolutionary frameworks established using molecular data on modern species.

On a smaller scale, we have also tackled the problem of adding morphological data for extant species into phylogenetic analyses in order to get more robust fossil-and-modern phylogenies of Carnivora. This work has led to a phylogeny of feliforms (cat-like carnivores) that reveals more about the evolution of saber-toothed carnivores in the fossil record. While that work is yet to be published, it has shown how extinct groups of saber-toothed carnivores relate to one another using an integrated dataset of cranial, dental, postcranial, and molecular data.

In addition to studies that integrate modern and fossil phylogenetic data, we have studied a variety of problems related to macroevolution of diet in fossil mammals. Our study of the relationship between body mass and diet in mammals demonstrated that different diets have different influence on the evolution of size among mammals. Another study using modern data showed relationships between reproductive strategies, diet, and size, showing that diet colors the relationship between parental care and adult size. Our results showed that greater parental care is correlated with large size in omnivores and herbivores, but differences in ecology between carnivorous mammals mean that the relationship between size and parental care in species that eat meat and arthropods are complicated. Additional studies as part of this project have explored the structure of mammalian diets and the morphological relationship between diet and dental morphology.

In addition to the research outcomes of this study, we have used the course of the project to train nearly a dozen paleontology graduate students in phylogenetic comparative methods, equipping them to serve as the next generation of integrative biologists. They will have the tools to work back and forth between the modern and fossil records of evolution. A similar number of undergraduates have participated in the project, gaining experience working with techniques that span biology and paleontology. Finally, we have generated materials to teach macroevolution to high school students, an audience that is not commonly exposed to evolutionary content. By making these materials available to teachers, we will facilitate the teaching of some of the more accessible and charismatic evolutionary examples.
